evidence.dc:description:
This paper also provides evidence that the MRAS and SHOC2 proteins function in a Ternary complex as PP1 substrate specifying subunits. They conducted pulldown assays and mutated residues in SHOC2 to test for their affect on SHOC2's binding affinity with PP1. Found that the SILK and RVxF motifs were important for the binding affinity
This is the same group now providing further evidence showing that this subunit may be interacting with the SHOC2 protein. Since the mechanism of PP1's involvement in the complex is further investigated, an additional 0.25 points were given.
There is further evidence about the funciton of PP1 in the literature, however, these appear to be the only papers linking the gene to the disease phenotype.

dc:source.dc:abstract: SHOC2 is mutated in Noonan syndrome and plays a key role in the activation of the ERK-MAPK pathway, which is upregulated in the majority of human cancers. SHOC2 functions as a PP1-regulatory protein and as an effector of MRAS. Here we show that SHOC2 and MRAS form a complex with SCRIB, a polarity protein with tumor suppressor properties. SCRIB functions as a PP1-regulatory protein and antagonizes SHOC2-mediated RAF dephosphorylation through a mechanism involving competition for PP1 molecules within the same macromolecular complex. SHOC2 function is selectively required for the malignant properties of tumor cells with mutant RAS, and both MRAS and SHOC2 play a key role in polarized migration. We propose that MRAS, through its ability to recruit a complex with paradoxical components, coordinates ERK pathway spatiotemporal dynamics with polarity and that this complex plays a key role during tumorigenic growth.
dc:source.dc:creator: Young LC
dc:source.dc:title: An MRAS, SHOC2, and SCRIB complex coordinates ERK pathway activation with polarity and tumorigenic growth.

evidence.rdfs:label: PP1 interaction with MRAS and SHOC2

evidence.dc:description:
RAS family GTPases (RFGs) were studied with TAP purification of M-Ras interacting proteins in HEK293 cells. They found that there was an in vivo interaction of SHOC2 and PP1c aka the catalytic subunit of PP1. Using pulldown assays, they found that in vitro, a trimeric complex was formed between Shoc2 and PP1c that was dependent on M-Ras-GTP. They also found that the binding of Shoc2 and PP1c to M-Ras leads to Raf P-S259 dephosphorylation.
SHOC2 is known to cause NS/LAH (i.e. the c.4A>G variant) therefore, PPP1CB's interaction with SHOC2 supports its ability to cause NS/LAH

dc:source.dc:abstract: Ras family GTPases (RFGs) are known to share many regulatory and effector proteins. How signaling and biological specificity is achieved is poorly understood. Using a proteomics approach, we have identified a complex comprised of Shoc2/Sur-8 and the catalytic subunit of protein phosphatase 1 (PP1c) as a highly specific M-Ras effector. M-Ras targets Shoc2-PP1c to stimulate Raf activity by dephosphorylating the S259 inhibitory site of Raf proteins bound to other molecules of M-Ras or Ras. Therefore, distinct RFGs, through independent effectors, can regulate different steps in the activation of Raf kinases. Shoc2 function is essential for activation of the MAPK pathway by growth factors. Furthermore, in tumor cells with Ras gene mutations, inhibition of Shoc2 expression inhibits MAPK, but not PI3K activity. We propose that the Shoc2-PP1c holoenzyme provides an attractive therapeutic target for inhibition of the MAPK pathway in cancer.
dc:source.dc:creator: Rodriguez-Viciana P
dc:source.dc:title: A phosphatase holoenzyme comprised of Shoc2/Sur8 and the catalytic subunit of PP1 functions as an M-Ras effector to modulate Raf activity.

evidence.rdfs:label: PP1 interacts with SHOC2

evidence.dc:description: SHOC2 is Definitively assoicated only with NS/LAH and therefore it is specific to the NS/LAH phenotype. However this should be the only evidence scored implicating that this gene'e spresence in the RAS/MAPK pathway because many of the RASopathy genes studied have an interacting partner in the RAS/MAPK pathway except LZTR1

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: severe ID, growth reardation and some dysmorphic features.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: uneventful pregnancy, C-section due to breech presentation, walked at 6 years, nonverbal at age 13 years, could not communicate with pictogram. No social smile, no regression, no seizures, anxiety, large mouth, malar hypoplasia, no eye contact. CT revealed mild increased CSF spaces.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Genetics is believed to have an important role in intellectual disability (ID). Recent studies have emphasized the involvement of de novo mutations (DNMs) in ID but the extent to which they contribute to its pathogenesis and the identity of the corresponding genes remain largely unknown. Here, we report a screen for DNMs in subjects with moderate or severe ID. We sequenced the exomes of 41 probands and their parents, and confirmed 81 DNMs affecting the coding sequence or consensus splice sites (1.98 DNMs/proband). We observed a significant excess of de novo single nucleotide substitutions and loss-of-function mutations in these cases compared to control subjects, suggesting that at least a subset of these variations are pathogenic. A total of 12 likely pathogenic DNMs were identified in genes previously associated with ID (ARID1B, CHD2, FOXG1, GABRB3, GATAD2B, GRIN2B, MBD5, MED13L, SETBP1, TBR1, TCF4, WDR45), resulting in a diagnostic yield of ∼29%. We also identified 12 possibly pathogenic DNMs in genes (HNRNPU, WAC, RYR2, SET, EGR1, MYH10, EIF2C1, COL4A3BP, CHMP2A, PPP1CB, VPS4A, PPP2R2B) that have not previously been causally linked to ID. Interestingly, no case was explained by inherited mutations. Protein network analysis indicated that the products of many of these known and candidate genes interact with each other or with products of other ID-associated genes further supporting their involvement in ID. We conclude that DNMs represent a major cause of moderate or severe ID.
dc:source.dc:creator: Hamdan FF
dc:source.dc:title: De novo mutations in moderate or severe intellectual disability.

evidence.dc:description: This individual was not evaluated or diagnosed with Noonan-like syndrome with loose anagen hair and no hair phenotype was reported, therefore the variant was not scored. However, there are several overlapping features with the syndrome reported.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Noonan syndrome-like disorder with loose anagen hair,Sparse, thin and slow growing hair, coronal craniosynostosis, relative macrocephaly, delayed development pectus cariantum/excavatum, patent ductus arteriosus
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Cranioplasty at 1y9m, normal EEG, detected heart defects and other clinical features.

dc:source.dc:abstract: We report on a 12-year-old Brazilian boy with the p.Pro49Arg mutation in PPP1CB, a novel gene associated with RASopathies. This is the fifth individual described, and the fourth presenting the same variant, suggesting a mutational hotspot. Phenotypically, he also showed the same hair pattern-sparse, thin, and with slow growing-, similar to the typical ectodermal finding observed in Noonan syndrome-like disorder with loose anagen hair. Additionally, he presented craniosynostosis, a rare clinical finding in RASopathies. This report gives further support that this novel RASopathy-PPP1CB-related Noonan syndrome with loose anagen hair-shares great similarity to Noonan syndrome-like disorder with loose anagen hair, and expands the phenotypic spectrum by adding the cranial vault abnormality. © 2017 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
dc:source.dc:creator: Bertola D
dc:source.dc:title: The recurrent PPP1CB mutation p.Pro49Arg in an additional Noonan-like syndrome individual: Broadening the clinical phenotype.

evidence.rdfs:label: Bertola_1 (Brazil)

evidence.dc:description: This variant was scored because of previous de novo occurances however, parental DNA was not assessed in this patient. The variant was absent from gnomAD, predicted to be damaging.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: prominent forehead, broad eyebrows, broad nose, thin upper lip, delayed development and speech, atrial septal defect, joint hypermobility doughy skin, constipation, dysphagia
evidence.previousTestingDescription: All 8 patients were evaluated using WES, variants were confirmed with Sanger sequencing and absence from parents was also confirmed.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Intellectual disabilities are genetically heterogeneous and can be associated with congenital anomalies. Using whole-exome sequencing (WES), we identified five different de novo missense variants in the protein phosphatase-1 catalytic subunit beta (PPP1CB) gene in eight unrelated individuals who share an overlapping phenotype of dysmorphic features, macrocephaly, developmental delay or intellectual disability (ID), congenital heart disease, short stature, and skeletal and connective tissue abnormalities. Protein phosphatase-1 (PP1) is a serine/threonine-specific protein phosphatase involved in the dephosphorylation of a variety of proteins. The PPP1CB gene encodes a PP1 subunit that regulates the level of protein phosphorylation. All five altered amino acids we observed are highly conserved among the PP1 subunit family, and all are predicted to disrupt PP1 subunit binding and impair dephosphorylation. Our data suggest that our heterozygous de novo PPP1CB pathogenic variants are associated with syndromic intellectual disability.
dc:source.dc:creator: Ma L
dc:source.dc:title: De novo missense variants in PPP1CB are associated with intellectual disability and congenital heart disease.

This variant is not present in gnomAD.
This patient did not present with any hair phenotype, though there is evidence of a rasopathy. This is not convincing evidence against the gene-disease association, however the phenotype does not match prior cases enough to provide support.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Noonan syndrome-like disorder with loose anagen hair, Delayed development, relative or absolute macrocephaly, hair abnormalities and low-set, posteriorly angulated ears

dc:source.dc:abstract: Noonan syndrome is a rasopathy caused by mutations in multiple genes encoding components of the RAS/MAPK pathway. Despite its variable phenotype, limited genotype-phenotype correlations exist. Noonan syndrome with loose anagen hair (NS-LAH) is characterized by its distinctive hair anomalies, developmental differences, and structural brain abnormalities and is caused by a single recurrent missense SHOC2 mutation. SHOC2 forms a complex with protein phosphatase 1 (PP1C). Protein phosphatases counterbalance kinases and control activation of signaling proteins, such as the mitogen-activated protein kinases of the RAS/MAPK pathway. Here we report four patients with de novo missense mutations in protein phosphatase one catalytic subunit beta (PPP1CB), sharing a recognizable phenotype. Three individuals had the recurrent PPP1CB c.146G>C, p.Pro49Arg mutation, the fourth had a c.166G>C, p.Ala56Pro change. All had relative or absolute macrocephaly, low-set and posteriorly angulated ears, and developmental delay. Slow growing and/or sparse hair and/or an unruly hair texture was present in all. Three individuals had feeding difficulties requiring feeding tubes. One of two males had cryptorchidism, another had pectus excavatum. Short stature was present in three. A female with the recurrent mutation had a Dandy-Walker malformation and optic nerve hypoplasia. Mild ventriculomegaly occurred in all, cerebellar tonsillar ectopia was seen in two and progressed to Chiari 1 malformation in one individual. Based on the combination of phenotypic findings and PPP1CB's effect on RAF dephosphorylation within the RAS/MAPK pathway, this novel condition can be considered a rasopathy, most similar to NS-LAH. Collectively, these mutations meet the standardized criteria for pathogenicity. © 2016 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
dc:source.dc:creator: Gripp KW
dc:source.dc:title: A novel rasopathy caused by recurrent de novo missense mutations in PPP1CB closely resembles Noonan syndrome with loose anagen hair.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2 (USA)

evidence.dc:description: This variant is not present in gnomAD. All individuals in study had a condition extremely similar to Noonan syndrome or a similar RASopathy with some sort of hair abnormality consistent with loose anagen hair. The study concluded that this condition could be deemed a novel rasopathy provisionally termed PPP1CB related Noonan syndrome with loose anagen hair (P-NS-LAH) however for the purposes of this curation, all cases were counted towards NS-LAH.

evidence.rdfs:label: Zambrano_1 (origin not specified) non consanguineous

evidence.dc:description:
This variant is not present in gnomAD.
This variant was found to be de novo in this patient and was predicted to be pathogenic by several computational tools.

dc:description: PPP1CB was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant Noonan syndrome with loose anagen hair (AD NS-LAH) as early as 2016 (Gripp et al., PMID: 27264673). At least 4 unique missense variants (including the recurrent de novo p.Pro49Arg variant) have been reported in humans with this disorder. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 10 probands in 5 publications (PMID: 25356899, 27264673, 27681385, 27868344, 28211982). More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence has been reached (PMID: 30236064). The mechanism of disease is thought to result in more stable/prolonged binding of SHOC2 and PPP1C to MRAS, which is expected to promote a more effective/prolonged RAF p.Ser259 dephosphorylation (PMID: 26446362, 23875798, 16630891). This gene-disease association is supported by relevant experimental evidence implicating a physical association of PP1c (of which PPP1CB is a subunit) with SHOC2, which is definitively associated with NS-LAH (PMID: 16630891, 24211266). The ClinGen RASopathy Expert Panel has assessed PPP1CB for associations with Noonan syndrome, Noonan syndrome with multiple lentigines, Costello syndrome, and cardiofaciocutaneous syndrome, however no evidence was reported. In summary, PPP1CB is definitively associated with AD NS-LAH. This curation was approved by the ClinGen RASopathy Expert Panel on 4/23/20 (SOP Version 7).
